clean_story:
One mind.  No compromise.
The phrase "lone inventor" isn’t about solitude—it’s about unfiltered execution.
A committee debates a bridge’s design for months. A lone engineer sketches it on a napkin,  builds a prototype in a garage,  and tests it by walking across.
Speed isn’t the only advantage—it’s the absence of dilution.
Every added voice in a group softens sharp ideas. Like passing a whispered secret down a line,  the final version barely resembles the original.
Thomas Edison didn’t invent the light bulb in a boardroom. He tested 6,000 materials for filaments—alone,  failing 5,999 times before carbonized bamboo worked. A committee would’ve stopped at 100 attempts,  citing "diminishing returns. "
Lone inventors also cheat the system. They repurpose what exists—like Gunpei Yokoi turning a discarded calculator chip into the Game Boy’s brain. Committees demand "new. " Inventors demand "works. "
Even failures move faster. Nikola Tesla’s unbuilt "death ray" was a dead end,  but his solo experiments with alternating current now power cities. A committee’s failed project? A canceled budget line.
Three related subjects are rapid prototyping tricks,  why constraints fuel creativity,  and how patents kill momentum.
